item.title: Report E-2024100382
item.description:
Report E-2024100382

Identified by scraper @ 2024-10-17T09:14:53+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-10-10
  • City: DUNCAN
  • State: SC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: During a routine vehicle inspection at the job site, Veolia employees discovered paint dripping from a drum. Upon investigation, they determined that the leaking drum had been collected from a previous customer, Hentzen. The employees located the source of the leak, which was coming from the top of the drum. After a thorough inspection, the seal was identified as the cause of the problem. The employees theorized that the truck's vibration during transport had caused the paint to seep through the faulty top seal. Fortunately, the spill was contained within the truck, and no paint had leaked outside while the vehicle was in motion. The team took immediate action to address the situation. They contained the spill and overpacked the drum, along with all materials used in the cleanup process. This prompt response ensured that the incident was managed efficiently and safely, minimizing any potential environmental impact or further complications.

item.title: Report X-2024101009
item.description:
Report X-2024101009

Identified by scraper @ 2024-10-17T09:14:53+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-10-10
  • City: NEW YORK
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: AN AIR PACKAGE AT THE DELIVERY DESTINATION CENTER NEEDED ADDITIONAL TAPING DUE TO THE SEAL OF ONE END OF THE BOX BROKE OPEN. WHILE RETAPING WE DISCOVERED IPHONES WERE INSIDE THE UNMARKED PACKAGE. FULL CONTENT INSPECTION REVEALS 17 USED IPHONES. AT LEAST FOUR OF THE IPHONES POWER ON WITH A LOW BATTERY STATUS. THE ADDITIONAL IPHONES DO NOT HAVE ENOUGH CHARGE TO POWER ON. THE CELL PHONES WERE INDIVIDUALLY WRAPPED IN BUBBLE WRAP. THEY WERE THEN PLACED IN GROUPS OF THREE ON BUBBLE WRAP AND FOLDED A FEW TIMES REPEATING UNTIL ALL WERE WRAPPED INTO ONE BUNDLE. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BOX. PRIOR TO THE UNDECLARED DISCOVERY, THE PACKAGE WAS FLOWN ON UPS AIRCRAFT.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2024-10-17T09:14:53+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-10-04
  • City: SEABROOK
  • State: NH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On October 4, 2024, one (1) 55-gallon drum of sulfuric acid was damaged due to unknown causes and released approximately five (5) gallons of product to the trailer interior, tires, concrete, and facility processing drain. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Green Site Services Group, Inc. (GSSG) to remediate the impacted site. The damaged drum was placed into one (1) 95-gallon overpack drum for transport and disposal. A neutralizing agent was deployed to the impacted areas. Once the area was properly neutralized, the crew deployed soda ash to the impacted areas and worked them in with hand tools. The impacted material was collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum for transport and disposal.

  • Description: DRIVER STATES PACKAGE WAS BEING LOADED INTO PACKAGE CAR AROUND 9:45 AM, ONCE PLACED ON FLOOR OF PACKAGE CAR THE PACKAGE BEGINS TO SMOKE AND MAKE HISSING NOISES THEN "EXPLODED" BUSTING THE BOX APART. DRIVER AND LOADER STEPPED AWAY FROM PACKAGE AND CALLED SUPERVISOR OVER TO PACKAGE CAR TO OBSERVE DAMAGE. NO OTHER PACKAGES WERE DAMAGED AND NO ONE WAS INJURED. DRIVER REMOVED PACKAGE FROM PACKAGE CAR. UPS DRIVER BROUGHT THE PACKAGE IN DUE TO A POSSIBLE LEAK. WHEN THE PACKAGE WAS PUT DOWN THEY HEARD A LOUD NOISE. THE FIRE EXTINGUISHER LEAKED ITS CONTENTS. THIS IS WHY THE GAUGE IS AT 0 IN THE PHOTOS. FIRE EXTINGUISHERS; INNER BOX HAS A 2.2 DOT NON FLAMMABLE GAS DIAMOND LABEL

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 9/25/2024 at approximately 1030, Dangerous Goods Administration received a call from Employee 957951 at the ramp facility in Sacramento, reporting a dangerous goods spill. The shipment consisted of one fiberboard box, containing two fiberboard boxes with a fire extinguisher in each inner box. The shipment was discovered showing a powder residue on the outer package and on the aircraft floor. Further investigation revealed that the shipment contained fire extinguishers that were missing the secure pin. Additionally, the package was not prepared in accordance with IATA regulations, missing the required markings, labeling, packaging and paperwork on the outermost pacakge. The shipment is being held, pending in FAA investigation.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 09/20/2024, at 0857 hours, CSX personnel reported UTLX 208840, a loaded tank car containing Alcohols, N.O.S., leaking from top of the tank car. The car was isolated and the shipper, Poet Bioprocessing, was notified via Ambipar (Report #20240920-01-02787). CSX Senior Manager of Hazardous Materials Rob James responded to the scene and found five of eight manway cover bolts less than tool tight. Mr. James inspected the car to ensure there were no notable defects to the manway cover, gasket, or nozzle, and secured all manway cover bolts tool tight to secure the product release. The issue identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shippers representative- Jared Ayers (316-213-2805). Upon proper securement the car was released for transportation.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XTM experienced a UN3266 PI-2100 release from a 55-gallon poly drum. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 55-gallons of product released to a 15 x 20 area of the concrete dock floor. Prior to their arrival, XPO placed wood chips and absorbents down to contain the release. The damaged drum was placed into an 85-gallon poly overpack. Absorbents were then worked into the impacted area. All impacted absorbents, wood chips, cleanup debris, and the impacted pallet were containerized into 2 flex bins and (3) 55-gallon poly drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 11000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On October 10, 2024, at 1154 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Landstar personnel in Euclid, OH regarding the release of Paraformaldehyde Prills 91-93%. Contractors were dispatched to the site to perform all onsite clean-up activities. Upon arrival, contractors confirmed the release of 150 lbs of Paraformaldehyde Prills 91-93% (UN2213, 4.1, III) from (3) bags onto the trailer floor. The release was reportedly due to impact from pallets during loading, affecting multiple areas in the trailer. No drains or waterways were impacted by the release. The contractors collected the release with the proper PPE. All waste generated from addressing this release was containerized in (2) 55-gallon DF, which were then taken off site by contractors for proper disposal.

  • Description: On October 3, 2024, one (1) 50-pound bag of UN1823 was torn during unloading and released approximately two (2) pounds of product to the loading dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Hull's Environmental Services (HES) to remediate the impacted site. HES deployed and absorbents and utilized hand tools to remediate the area. All impacted debris was collected and containerized into one (1) 5-gallon bucket for disposal. HES removed the one (1) damaged bag of sodium hydroxide powder and placed it into a 55-gallon drum for disposal.

The spill was coming from the bottom of a pallet containing a drum classified as UN3082 Class 9. After cargo breakdown, minor scratches and cracks were found at the bottom of the blue steel drum. The shipment was placed on hold and removed from the aircraft.

item.description:
Report E-2024100302

Identified by scraper @ 2024-10-12T21:13:18+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-10-08
  • City: PRINCETON
  • State: IN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On October 8, 2024, one (1) 55-gallon drum of UN2924 was punctured and released approximately one-half (0.5) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Enhanced Environmental and Emergency (E3) to remediate the impacted site. E3 personnel placed the damaged 55-gallon drum into one (1) 85-gallon salvage drum that was labeled as salvaged material for return to the terminal. The released material had dried by the time crews arrived, so crews inspected the trailer to ensure no further remediation was needed.

item.title: Report X-2024100686
item.description:
Report X-2024100686

Identified by scraper @ 2024-10-12T21:13:18+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-10-05
  • City: DENVER
  • State: CO
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On October 4th during the PM sort a package was discovered that had a distinct sound of an aerosol can. After calling DG Admin the station opened the package and found three cans of spray paint. There are no markings or labels on the outside of the package that indicates the package contains any dangerous goods, however a safety data sheet classifies these as UN1950, Aerosols, flammable, 2.1. The package is being help pending investigation of the FAA.

  • Description: AT THE UPS FACILITY IN FREMONT, CALIFORNIA, ONE AIR PACKAGE TO MALAYSIA WAS BEING INSPECTED PRIOR TO EXPORT. THE OUTER BOX IS ULINE HAZARDOUS MATERIALS PACKAGING WITH FOUR OSHA NFPA LABELS APPLIED INDICATING FLAMMABILITY HAZARD 1, HEALTH HAZARD 2 AND INSTABILITY HAZARD 0. PACKAGE CONTENT INSPECTION REVEALS A FIVE GALLON 1A1 STEEL DRUM OF FLAMMABLE SHELL D-38, MINERAL SPIRITS 66.1% AROM. THE OSHA NFPA LABEL ON THE STEEL DRUM INDICATES FLAMMABILITY HAZARD 2 WITH A FLASH POINT RANGE OF 104 - 115 F, WHICH IS REGULATED IN AIR TRANSPORTATION. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BOX. THIS PACKAGE HAS NOT BEEN ACCEPTED FOR AIR OR TRANSPORTED IN THE AIR BY UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.

Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 30-gallons of Baxxodur EC301 released to a 100 x 20 area of the asphalt lot and a 15 x 8 area of the trailer floor. The drum was punctured by a metal plate which slid within the trailer during transport. The damaged drum was placed into a 95-gallon poly overpack. Absorbents were then worked into the impacted areas to clean the release. The impacted absorbents were containerized into a 55-gallon metal drum. The waste was removed from site for disposal.

  • Description: On September 29, 2024, at 1107 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Landstar personnel in Elgin, Nebraska regarding the release of Acetone. Contractors were dispatched to the site to perform all onsite clean-up activities. Upon arrival, contractors confirmed the release of 16 ounces of Acetone (UN1090, 3, II) from (1) 275-gallon plastic tote. The release was reportedly due to a faulty nozzle, and there was no impact to the trailer floor as all material was caught on a rag. No drains or waterways were impacted by the release. Contactors transferred all remaining material to a new 275-gallon plastic tote. The damaged tote was the only waste generated from this incident which was then taken off site by the contractor for proper disposal.
